instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.820-3536A: What is 820-3536A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Have this <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> here which is missing its display and I sadly have no test displays. So I attempted to power it up and the fan spins but it doesn?t chime or output a signal to an external display. Anyone got a clue what could be going wrong?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message:
Is that <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board?
Any history available?
Did you try PRAM reset?

CPU VCORE is present?
Also check <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

Try known good working BIOS.
Check first all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and traces.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Oof completely forget the board number. Me idiot! It?s the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. I have no history on this one. When I pulled the board out I did notice a prior repair though which always sucks. They ran a jumper from L1295 to <CAPACITOR>C1297</CAPACITOR> as well as replaced <CAPACITOR>C7371</CAPACITOR>. I did try the normal resets without success. VCORE is 2.1V measured on <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR>. <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 0V. Don?t have a way to flash a new bios to the board atm. What sort of programmer would I need?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message:
No BIOS activity prior <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, so don't touch it yet.

"VCORE is 2.1V measured on <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR>"
Are you really sure?
Too high, check it with different voltmeter.
Also check <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL> level.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Used my old meter (not my nice PeakTech Unit) and got 1.728V. <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL> is 1.8V. Hope that helps

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message:
Change the battery of the other multimeter.
And do not spend lot of money on precision meters; not a real help!

Check for corrosion at <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>; post its voltages.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message:
Yup the battery did the trick! Now the values match my old meter. Voltages at <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> are:

Pin 1 - 3.3V
Pin 2 - 1.7V
Pin 3 - 0V
Pin 4 - GND
Pin 5 - 0V
Pin 6 - 0V
Pin 8 - 3.4V

hope those help

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message:
You've missed pin 7.
However not important, as pin 2 is not correctly defined.

Check <RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR>; if good, change <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Yeah didn?t include that on purpose as it?s a duplicate pin. What do you mean by good?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: If has correct ohm value...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Back to this old thread after over a month. Got a replacement <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> in, made no difference. Also tested the original one on a known booting board and it worked. Any other ideas on what I can try?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: You must get 3V at pin 2/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>...

threads.message: Only get about 1.7V...

threads.message:
Check <RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR>; does it have 3V on pin 1?
If yes, change <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Quick question: Is <CHIP>U2100</CHIP>/<CHIP>U7950</CHIP> on the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> compatible?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: All of them 74LVC2G08GT, so yes.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Do you have 3V at pin 1/<RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Yup I do. Pin 2 is 1.7 and Pin 1 3.3

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message:
Change again <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
Did you solder 10K into <RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR> place?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Yup. Tried two more and no change.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message:
Any corrosion there?
Input voltage cannot drop so much.
Be sure the chip is correctly soldered.
You can try to force the signal, soldering 1K instead of 10K resistor.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Well the board has seen liquid damage but the are looks fine. I’ll check the chip again and if not try the 1k resistor

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: So with the 1k resistor it has about 3.3V on both sides of the resistor. Still doesn’t work though… No display or anything.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Also still wondering why someone who worked on the board before me ran a jumper between Pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C1297</CAPACITOR> and Pin 2 of L1295… Someone seems to have already given up on this one or it failed later

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message:
Post all voltages for <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

Do you get voltage at L1295 (pad 2)?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: It’s 1.070V. Also now know why the jumper, pad 2 was torn off the board

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message:
And for <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> we get:

Pin 1 - 3.3
Pin 2 - 3.3
Pin 3 - 3.4
Pin 4 - 0 (GND)
Pin 5 - 3.4
Pin 6 - 3.4
Pin 7 - 3.4
Pin 8 - 3.4

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Also super strange is the fact that pin 2 on <RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR> occasionally shows 1.8V despite using the 1k resistor. If I unplug and replug power it fixes it

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message:
If you get 3V at pin 3, is good.
Check if <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes high.

threads.message: Well isn’t that Pin 3?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Also I’ve noticed pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R1950</RESISTOR> seems to be at 3.3v for about 14s (estimate) before falling to 1.8. Same at Pin 1 so <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is falling

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message:
So <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> drops after 15s?
Which voltages remain present then?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Yes. You mean Voltages on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?

threads.message: In general, which voltages disappear from MLB?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: Usually the big coils, not too many...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message:
Okay:

L7130- 12.79
L7520- 5.18
L7320- 1.71
L7310- 1.70
L7630- 1.06
L7430- 1.36
L7710- 0V
L3095- 0V

hope those help. What a frustrating board as it’s so close to working with the cpu heating up, fan spin etc…

BTW I also noticed <RESISTOR>R6131</RESISTOR> wasn’t on the board near the SPI flash. Is that always not populated?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013 13? MacBook Pro Fan Spin, no chine or Display output
threads.message: If <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> drops to 1.8V, you should note more incorrect voltages.
